2 Scenarios We developed ten scenarios defined as the area used for the calculation of the caribou umbrella index: from 5% to 95% of the study area excluding water, in 10% increments. With landbirds density on water pixels being equal to zero, we excluded these pixels from BCUI assessment. 2.1 Scenario 5% Boxplot showing minimum and maximum (vertical lines), median (horizontal line), interquartile range (IQR, colored box), as well as outliers (black points) of boreal caribou umbrella indices (BCUI) by landbird habitat association calculated across time (2011 - 2091), climate projections (CanESM2, CCSM4 and INM-CM4) and replicates (n = 5), as well as the weighted average across these (in grey dashed line) for Scenario 5%. 3 Individual Species Results 3.1 Species Information 3.2 Species Results

3 Individual Species Results We used landbird density models based on climate, vegetation, and terrain variables, fitted as boosted regression trees; these were developed using avian point count data from the Boreal Avian Modelling (BAM) project database. The BAM database is a compilation of point-count data from projects spanning the boreal and hemi-boreal regions of North America (Cumming et al. 2010; Barker et al. 2015). BAMs human point-count survey data (1993 to 2018) were supplemented with sampling events extracted from autonomous recording units (ARU) deployed in the Northwest Territories and Alberta (2012 to 2018) by both the Canadian Wildlife Service and the University of Alberta Bioacoustic Unit (WildTrax, 2019). The species for this study were selected based on the availability of survey data and density offsets (Sólymos et al. 2013) to standardize point-count survey estimates. This resulted in models for 71 landbird species (Table 1). 3.1 Species Information The following table provides information on species and how these are generally classified: 3.2 Species Results The following sections present all individual species results: 1. 4 Output tables In this section we present all table outputs that were used to generate the information and plots in the results section. 4.1 Table 1 This table represents a linear model fitted with all data available to identify which covariates influence the calculation of BCUI results 4.2 Table 2 This table is a statistical summary of all data for each habitat group per scenario 4.3 Table 3 This table is a statistical summary of all data for habitat group across all scenarios 4.4 Table 4 This table is a statistical summary of all data for each species per scenario 4.5 Table 5 This table is a statistical summary of all data for individual species across all scenarios 4.6 Table 6 This table presents the trend through time for each habitat group per scenario 4.7 Table 7 This table presents the trend through time for each species per scenario

5 Repositories Here you can find the repository for the whole simulation and analysis: https://github.com/tati-micheletti/NWT/tree/development More specifically, these are the scripts used for the following: Simulations: https://github.com/tati-micheletti/NWT/blob/development/5_runningSimulations.R Umbrella analysis: https://github.com/tati-micheletti/NWT/blob/development/7_hotspotsAnalysis_V2.R The following modules were used for the predictions: Caribou predictions: https://github.com/tati-micheletti/caribouRSF_NT Landbird predictions: https://github.com/tati-micheletti/birdsNWT
